Award.AwardTitle: Entanglement in Biology-Pierced Lassos and Deep Knots
Award.AbstractNarration:
Unexpectedly, proteins can tie themselves into knots in their native folds. Since protein folding from an unstructured molecular chain into the native-state is already complex, the existence of knotted chains immediately raises the questions: how does the chain cross itself to form a knot and how does the knot affect function? The PIs discovered a class of proteins, with leptin as the founding member. This growing class now includes well over 350 protein families, spanning a huge range of fold types and including all secondary structure elements. The goal of the current project is to use a multifaceted approach to investigate how the fundamental mechanisms of knotting/unknotting/threading are initiated and relate to overall protein folding, and how the knotted functional and folding landscapes are related. One of the PIs has been involved in K-12 outreach by performing scientific experiments at local grammar schools which are greater than 50% minority students, by also helping to train children in middle school for the Science Olympiad, hosting High School students as research interns for the summer and by hosting people interested in a career in teaching in primary and secondary schools as research assistants in her laboratory. This effort will allow the PI to convey a true excitement for science to the K-12 population and she is currently in the planning stages of intensifying her K-12 outreach efforts by coordinating visits to local bilingual schools accompanied by successful minority, male and female students from UCSD that will provide role models for the local students.

The simplest backbone, deep-knotted proteins are the 31 trefoil knots such as in the trefoil methyltransferase (MT) families. The PIs showed that an extended time in the denatured state is required for unknotting in these proteins. The PIs will investigate whether specific regions identified as barriers to untying in the MTs also contribute to functional regulation and ligand gating in the native states because of long-range coupling of topologically frustrated regions. The preliminary data are consistent with this hypothesis. Further exploration building upon these foundational studies will allow the PIs to investigate the interplay between the strained topology inherent in a knotted conformation and communication between functional sites. These studies will allow the PIs to describe, for the first time, the physical-chemical variables necessary to overcome the topological barrier for initiating threading as well as the role of the PL on the functional dynamics of a protein

This project is being jointly supported by the Physics of Living Systems program in the Division of Physics and the Molecular Biophysics Cluster in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences.

Performance_Institution.Name: University of California at San Diego

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes and Impact of Proposed Research on the Scientific and General Community: Our project constitutes a true multidisciplinary effort based on mathematical and physical principles and protein engineering for the understanding of the formation of the complex topologies associated with protein knotting. The ability to understand the physical principles that direct the formation of biological structures with will not only provide fundamental insights into biological self-assembly processes, but also lend itself to building novel structures with new functions. This project arose from our recent pioneering experimental discoveries in investigating the origins of hysteresis in complex topologies, and led to our discovery of how to untie a knotted protein. This experimental advantage allowed us to ask the fundamental question in the protein theory field: How can a protein fold into a deeply knotted biologically active protein? To fully understand how nature controls the topology of proteins, extensive theoretical, numerical and experimental progress were required and necessitates the effort of top researchers working at the interface of mathematics, biology, chemistry, and physics. Our work bridged these fields, inspiring cutting-edge interdisciplinary collaborations. Ultimately, understanding the biophysical biochemistry of knotted proteins can be used to design and engineer a novel class of proteins that have superior mechanical and thermal stability properties.

Mentorship: In addition to the proposed research program, a major effort in our laboratory focuses on understanding the molecular basis for specific signaling molecule binding and organelle/cellular response. This work benefits from a number of strong collaborations between Chemistry, Physics and The School of Medicine and international collaborations with Joanna Sulkowska at the University of Warsaw, Rachel Nechushtai at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem and Shachi Gosavi at The National Center for Biological Sciences in Bangalor, India. Training of graduate students exposes them to nearly all disciplines in chemistry, mathematics, physics and biology and provides them with valuable experimental and theoretical skills (molecular biology, protein biochemistry, chemical synthesis, coordination chemistry, spectroscopic techniques, electrochemistry, crystallography) that will help them tackle complex scientific problems later in their careers.

Undergraduate research is a major component of our laboratory and have been actively involved in the UCSD Faculty Mentor Program. Participants in this program are required to submit an original research proposal, work on an individual project, write a scholarly report and present their research at the annual symposium. Undergraduate involvement in the lab also provides an important pedagogical and motivational tool for graduate students. Inspired by my own experiences as a graduate student, I assign each graduate student in the lab to supervise an undergraduate researcher in the initial stages of their research projects. My students have all taken to this challenge and can get a great sense of satisfaction in training the undergraduates to begin to become independent thinkers in science. I have had numerous undergraduate students as authors on manuscripts where they have actively taken part in both the research and writing of the published journal articles.

Outreach and Promoting Diversity: Since coming to UCSD I have been involved mentoring both underrepresented minorities and women (especially those starting families) for careers in the physical sciences. I have had fifteen minority students in my laboratory ranging from high school students to postdoctoral fellows. In addition, my laboratory has produced eighteen children. While this may seem irrelevant to some, one of the most common reasons for female scientists to leave the field is because of their inability to find the right balance between career and family needs. Providing a supportive environment while still holding high standards has allowed me to be a successful mentor of talented female students who still love science after beginning their families. In addition, I have been involved in K-12 outreach by performing scientific experiments at local grammar schools which are greater than 50% minority students, hosting High School students as research interns for the summer and by hosting people interested in a career in teaching in primary and secondary schools in my laboratory. I believe these efforts allow me to convey a true excitement for science to the K-12 population. In this way, we provide role models for the local students. As an added note, my professional accomplishments have coincided with the births of my two children, Trevor and Kayleigh, one of whom is a special needs child. I believe it is because I am open to discussing not only science but also the challenges that arise from raising children and managing a career that has led to so many students who want to start a family, had troubles with social and autistic disorders or health concerns to come to me for advice and support as they seek professional care. I don?t think the impact of this type of mentoring can be underscored enough.

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 01/19/2021
Modified by: Patricia A Jennings
